title: Keweenaw National Historical Park: Centennial Celebration
body: Explore This Park    Get Involved     NPS Centennial     Centennial Celebration              Centennial Celebration          Descriptions of events: Everything is free! Quincy 10:00 am to 1:00 pm Continuous activities from 10:00 am to 12:00 pm Sorting Quincy Copper: In this hands on activity, you'll get to try out manual and mechanical ways to extract and separate copper from poor rock. See models and photos of the historic methods and learn what it took to get the copper. Foundry Demo: The mines in the Copper Country had a huge demand for iron parts for their machinery. Watch ranger Karl demonstrate the green sand foundry technique that local iron foundries employed. Because copper melts at a lower temperature than iron, copper will be melted and poured into sand molds in front of your very eyes! Face Painting: Turn your face into your favorite animal from a National Park for the kids bike parade by local artist Anna Sanchez. 10:00 am Geocaching: Explore the Quincy surface to find the cache! After getting introduced to geocaching you'll have a chance to locate a cache during this 90 minute program. GPS units provided. Noon Centennial Presentation and Pasties: Join us for a presentation on the history of the National Park Service and Keweenaw National Historical Park. Then we're giving away mini-pasties and lemonade. Show up early, they will run out. Calumet 2:00 am to 8:00 pm Continuous activities from 2:00 pm to 6:00 pm Reading the Keweenaw Landscape: This session connects participants to the Keweenaw's rich geoheritage. Share your favorite places in the Keweenaw and learn about the powerful geologic forces that helped create them! Copper & Science: Copper-bearing ore in the Keweenaw was smashed into bits at area stamp mills. Then, rock and copper were separated on the riffles of a Wilfley table using water and specific gravity. Try the separation process yourself in this hands-on science and history lesson. Recyclable Creations: Get ready for the bike parade by making costume items out of recyclables. We have the materials, you bring your creativity. 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm Foundry Demo: The mines in the Copper Country had a huge demand for iron parts for their machinery. Watch ranger Karl demonstrate the green sand foundry technique that local iron foundries employed. Because copper melts at a lower temperature than iron, copper will be melted and poured into sand molds in front of your very eyes! 2:15 pm and 3:15 pm Jacobsville Sandstone Time Machine: Learn how our sandstone helped build America. Discover why the sandstone is red and white, how old it is, and its unique benefits. This activity is widely popular and fills up, so get there early. 2:30 pm, 3:30 pm, and 4:30 pm Building Tours: An exploration on the design and evolution of the Calumet and Hecla general office building. 4:00 pm to 6:00 pm Face Painting: Turn your face into your favorite animal from a National Park for the kids bike parade by local artist Anna Sanchez.  6:00 pm Kids Bike Parade: We're peddling from Aggasiz Park to the Visitor Center in our centennial best. Show off what you made earlier in the day to fit the theme, Animals of the National Parks. 7:00 pm Parade Prizes and Reception:  Live Music from 2:00 pm to 6:00 pm will feature the Monday Night All-Stars. The Monday Night All-Stars play an eclectic brand of old-time music. Diverse instrumentation drives their toe-tapping tunes. Clare Zuraw's hammer dulcimer plays melodies and harmonies with equal footing. Kevin Blackstone uses the clawhammer banjo and baritone ukulele to provide snap and backbone to the set. Dave Morehouse fills in the empty spaces with mandolin, fiddle, bouzouki, concertina, and accordion.
